entry.title: Re: Sales Order Changed to Complete when invoice status i...
entry.content:
Dear requester,

When the sales order item is partially delivered, even the invoice is not yet invoiced, it is possible to cancel the remaining quantity. Since there is no open quantity in the order, the sales order becomes completed even the invoice status is Not Started. The delivery status of the item will be updated to Finished after the cancellation is saved.

The user is still able to further invoice the outbound delivery invoice request, and the invoice will then update the invoice status to Finished in the sales order afterwards.

It is confirmed with development team that this is the current designed system behavior for both manual entered sales orders and intercompany sales orders.

Thanks,

Adie

entry.title: Including Tax Information in Purchase Order Creation on SAP S/4HANA Cloud: Utilizing BAdI
entry.content:
How to Include Tax Item Information on Purchase Order output form?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Including Tax Information in Purchase Order Creation...
entry.content:
In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, no standard CDS views are available to retrieve tax information during purchase order creation. As a result, tax values cannot be transferred to output messages at this stage.
If Tax values need to be printed on Purchase Order Forms, a custom logic implementation is required. 

Here is a potential workaround for this missing functionality:

 

1. Create custom field at item level for the Purchase Order.

2. Populate this custom field with the tax amount to be printed. Note that in the current SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition release, there are no standard CDS views available to directly retrieve tax rates or tax codes.

Workaround 1:

To implement the desired code logic, BAdI MM_PUR_S4_PO_MODIFY_ITEM can be utilized.

  • Use this BAdI to calculate the tax amount as needed.
  • I_PurOrdItmPricingElementAPI01 is not filled while the order is saved.
  • Implement the  BADI calculating the values on your own logic code. 


Workaround 2:

To implement the required code logic, the BAdI MMPUR_PO_OUTPUT_HEADER_EXT/ITEM can be used.

The BAdI MMPUR_PO_OUTPUT_HEADER_EXT/ITEM can be used to implement custom logic for VAT calculation during output generation. It should be noted that this BAdI does not update the custom fields at the database level; changes will only be reflected on the output form.

This BAdI is invoked during output determination, which takes place after the purchase order is created. At that stage, the structure I_PurOrdItmPricingElementAPI01 already contains the relevant condition type values.

3. Enable custom field for output as demonstrated in this blog.

4. Adjust custom form template with the new field included.

Disclaimer: Any custom logic implemented with BAdIs falls outside the scope of SAP Technical Support.

entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud : SAP Analytics Cloud のプロビジョニング
entry.content:
本ブログはSAP Business Data Cloud(SAP BDC)のプロビジョニング方法についてガイドします。
※本ブログの原文はこちらです。また、最新アップデート情報の確認のために、併せてSAP BDCのマニュアルもご確認ください。

このシリーズは、次の 5 つブログで構成されます。

Part 1: SAP for Me によるSAP BDCのプロビジョニング
Part 2: SAP Datasphere のプロビジョニング
Part 3: SAP Analytics Cloud のプロビジョニング
Part 4: SAP Databricks のプロビジョニング
Part 5: Intelligent Applications と Data Packages のインストール

今回は、「Part 3: SAP Analytics Cloud のプロビジョニング」です。

 

Part 3: SAP Analytics Cloud のプロビジョニング

本ブログでは、Business Data Cloud Core を介して SAP Analytics Cloud(SAC) をプロビジョニングする方法について説明します。

  1. BDCアプリケーションのプロビジョニングを開始します。今回はSAP Analytics Cloudのテナントを作成します。
  2. 表示される「SAP Analytics Cloudのプロビジョニング」ダイアログで、ソリューション名、リソースグループ、ビジネスタイプなどの詳細を入力します。
  3. ビジネスタイプでは、「テスト」または「本番」を選択できます。
  4. 「クォータ割り当て」セクションで、テナントのユーザー数を指定します。この数値は、SAP Business Data Cloudで利用可能な総Capacity Unitのうち、SAP Analytics Cloud に割り当てられるCapacity Unit 数に影響します。
  5. テスト環境の場合は、最低20人のユーザーを指定する必要があります。
  6. 本番環境を選択する場合、最低25人のSAC BIユーザーが必要です。また、SAC Planningを利用する場合は最低1人のPlanning Professionalユーザーと10人のPlanning Standardユーザーのいずれかを指定する必要があります。この最低要件を満たしていれば、利用可能なライセンスの種類は任意に組み合わせることができます。
  7. 設定パラメータセクションには、地域、システム所有者のメールアドレス、名前などの入力情報が含まれています。BDC コックピットのプロビジョニングに以前選択した地域と同じ地域を選択してください。
  8. 設定情報を確認して、情報を送信してください。
  9. プロビジョニングリクエストが送信されたことを通知する確認メッセージが表示されます。
  10. 指定されたリソースグループ内のテナントを表示するには、「リソースで表示」をクリックします。
  11. リソースタブでは、ソリューションのステータスは「処理中」で、プロビジョニングが完了すると「準備完了」に変わります。
  12. プロビジョニング時に指定されたSAP Analytics Cloudのシステム所有者は、テナントがプロビジョニングされると電子メール通知を受け取ります。
  13. テナントの準備ができたら、「リソース」タブの下のリンクとテナントの詳細からテナントにアクセスできるようになります。
  14. 「顧客ランドスケープ」では、新しいテナントのシステムの詳細を確認できます。また、システム統合が視覚的に表示されるため、システムランドスケープの理解と操作が容易になります。
  15. 既に作成したBDCテナントを追加した「Formation」にテナントを追加する必要があります。
  16. 製品とポートフォリオ > Business Data Cloud > 顧客ランドスケープ > Formation に移動します。
  17. 正しいFormationを選択し、「システムを含める」をクリックして、Formationに含めるSACテナントを選択し、変更を保存します。
  18. 単一のSAP Analytics Cloudテナントは、1つのFormationにのみ属することができ、複数のフォーメーションに属することはできません。

これで、BDC Core内でSAP Analytics Cloudテナントが正常にプロビジョニングされました。


※ このブログの原文を書いてくれたShreyasri Boseに感謝します。

entry.title: Re: Error deleting BP ID via FM BAPI_IDENTIFICATION_REMOV...
entry.content:
You should be aware, direct updates to master data tables like BUT0ID are not recommended without SAP’s guidance. Of course, you can standardize all BP Identification Numbers to uppercase before deletion. This involves reading the existing entries from table BUT0ID, Converting the IDENTIFICATIONNUMBER field to uppercase using ABAP logic, Updating the entries via a custom report or enhancement (if allowed). Then retrying BAPI_IDENTIFICATION_REMOVE with the uppercase value.

If the above option is not viable or if data integrity is at risk, raise an incident with SAP Support referencing SAP Note 2745718. Request a workaround or enhancement that allows deletion regardless of case sensitivity. SAP may provide a patch or alternative FM that bypasses the uppercase check.

entry.title: Consolidating Customer Planning: Unleash Growth with SAP Revenue Growth Management’s Account Plan
entry.content:
1. The Fragmented Reality of CPG Account Management

For Key Account Managers (KAMs) in the consumer products industry, managing complex customer promotion plans is often a juggling act. You’ve probably experienced the frustration of scattered information of accounts, baseline volumes, targets & measures, assortments, and trade funds—all while struggling to align your promotions with corporate KPIs. This fragmentation isn’t just inefficient; it obscures strategic insights, delays adjustments, and risks revenue leakage.

 

2. SAP Revenue Growth Management: The Unified Engine

SAP Revenue Growth Management transforms how Consumer Packaged Goods (CPG) companies drive profitability. By integrating trade promotion, funds management, and analytics into a single platform, our solution turns raw data into actionable growth levers. At its core is the Account Plan —a dynamic workspace where KAMs centralize customer strategy, align resources, and track progress against goals. Unlike siloed systems, SAP Revenue Growth Management (RGM) consolidates data across promotions, baselines, and financial targets, ensuring every action ladders up to the profit and loss (P&L).

For more information on our current capabilities, see An Overview of SAP Revenue Growth Management.  

 

3. Account Planning in Action: Three Keys to Customer-Centric Trade Promotion Success

Here’s how the Account Plan in SAP Revenue Growth Management addresses your core challenges and supports your success:

 

3.1. Centralized Customer Account Intelligence: The Heart of Your Revenue Growth Management Strategy

Building an effective promotion plan starts with knowing your customer — from the available trade funds and product lists to baseline volumes and planned promotions. The Account Plan within SAP Revenue Growth Management centralizes all this critical information in one place, giving KAMs a holistic view of their account KPIs and metrics. 

  • Holistic Baseline and Assortment Management

The Account Plan integrates baselines—whether imported from demand planning systems or uploaded and maintained manually—mapped clearly to the product lists assigned to that account, creating a solid foundation for promotion management. 

  • Integrated Promotion and Fund Tracking

Within an Account Plan, a KAM can have a whole picture into all related promotions and manage planned promotions directly, either in a list view or in a calendar view, along with associated trade funds allocated and tracked via SAP Revenue Growth Management’s funds management feature. This integration allows KAMs to monitor investment allocation and consumption against plan targets, avoiding surprises.

This centralization cuts tedious manual data compilation and gives KAMs a clear “single source of truth” to guide their day-to-day decisions and ultimately meet growth targets. 

 

3.2. Agile Assortment Control:  Automated Selection and User Flexibility

Not every retailer stocks the same products year-round — seasonal items, product launches, discontinuations, and regional preferences all demand flexible planning. Additionally, the product list may differ for each retailer. To effectively manage this, SAP Revenue Growth Management leverages central assortments for efficiency while enabling KAMs to keep granular control to adapt to customer-specific needs.

  • Automated Determination of Central Assortments

Assortments are predefined groups of products assigned to specific customers and sales areas for designated time periods. SAP Revenue Growth Management automatically applies the most relevant central assortment at the lowest (i.e., most granular) customer level to one or more respective account plans, sparing KAMs unnecessary manual effort.

  • User-Friendly Overrides with Product Lists

While the central assortment sets the default product scope, KAMs have the flexibility to make specific modifications on a per-account basis under the Product List, including adding or removing products and editing product validity periods that define when a product is available for inclusion into a promotion plan. These manual changes do not affect the central assortment usually managed by administrators but are clearly shown in the user interface, helping KAMs review modifications and avoid errors. 

By combining automated assortment determination with controlled flexibility, the Account Plan stays both efficient and aligned with real-world customer agreements and ever-changing market demands.

 

3.3 Intuitive Account Plan Dashboard: Visualizing Plans to Drive Actions 

Keeping multiple account plans at different levels of the customer hierarchy organized and tracked can be challenging, especially if you manage numerous retailers or regions. With SAP Revenue Growth Management, KAMs always have clear visibility into their planning progress.

  • Quick Overview with Customizable KPIs

From a predefined list, KAMs can select up to four KPIs (e.g., trade spend, volume, gross sales value, trade rate) most relevant to each account plan. Moreover, based on business requirements and priorities, one KPI can be pinned for primary display on the dashboard, empowering KAMs to monitor progress towards targets and easily identify areas requiring action. 

  • Visual Indicators for Plan Readiness

The Account Plan Dashboard page provides a quick and effective overview of the situation across all account plans managed by a KAM. On the dashboard, the pinned KPI is color-coded, green for solid plans likely to achieve goals based on current planning data and red for accounts with overspent funds or unmet goals, with key figures for other selected KPIs displayed, making it fast and intuitive to spot risks or areas needing attention, so KAMs can adjust plans and prioritize actions confidently.

This color-coded dashboard insight helps KAMs stay on top of their portfolio’s health and proactively enhance plans, maximizing their growth contribution. 

 

4. Co-Innovation: Your Strategic Partner for Customer Account Success

The Account Plan in SAP Revenue Growth Management is more than a data repository—it’s an agile, integrated workspace designed to simplify your customer account planning while driving profitability.

If you face challenges such as:

  • not having a unified dynamic workspace that consolidates key business data
  • managing seasonal product lists in an intuitive way
  • limited visibility into promotion plans and revenue targets

Join our co-innovation program, where you can collaborate with us to shape the future of the Account Plan, unlocking new capabilities that address your business needs. 

Contact us today to get started! mail RGM_Engage@sap.com to get involved and help create the next generation of revenue growth excellence.

 

More Information

Account Plan Document on SAP Help Portal

Topic Page for SAP Revenue Growth Management

  • Unlocking Trade Spend Control Efficiency with Funds Management in SAP Revenue Growth Management
  • Decoding Promotional Success: Embedded Analytics in SAP Revenue Growth Management
  • Introducing Calendar View in SAP Revenue Growth Management: A Visual Leap for Strategic Planning
  • Consolidating Customer Planning: Unleash Growth with SAP Revenue Growth Management’s Account Plan

entry.title: Missing Post Processing for Odata Inteface - S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
I’m currently facing a challenge regarding interface design in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud environment.

My goal is to implement an interface that fulfills two key requirements:

  1. It must support post-processing and monitoring through the Application Interface Framework (AIF) in S/4HANA Public Cloud.
  2. It must provide an immediate response with clear error codes and messages, which can be forwarded to third-party systems.

    Unfortunately, I can’t achieve both at the same time with the current options. I’m forced to make a compromise:

    • With OData APIs, I do receive immediate error messages, which is ideal for integrating with third-party systems. However, OData interfaces do not support AIF, which means I lose important capabilities like system monitoring and post-processing.
    • On the other hand, asynchronous SOAP APIs are compatible with AIF and support post-processing and monitoring. But they don’t return immediate responses, making it hard to forward real-time errors to third-party systems.

      I’m working with business scenarios like Purchase Orders, Supplier Confirmations, Inbound Deliveries, and Supplier Invoices. Each of these either:

      • Offers OData APIs with no AIF support, or
      • Provides SOAP APIs, but only asynchronous ones without real-time feedback.

        At the moment, no matter which approach I choose—OData or SOAP—I seem to miss out on a crucial feature. Has anyone found a workaround or best practice to bridge this gap?

        Thank you!

        kind regards, 

        Philipp

entry.title: Re: Receiving process enhancement
entry.content: One option is you can use Process-Oriented Storage Control (POSC) which allows you to define a multi-step receiving process that can include batch handling, quality inspection, and putaway in one flow. You can configure a single warehouse process type that triggers batch selection and task creation together. This reduces manual steps and ensures consistent execution.

entry.title: SAP Cloud ALM Integration & Exception Monitoring "Frequency of event calculations" param is fixed
entry.content:
HI ,

I have setup connection between SAP CPI dev to SAP Cloud ALM. The service connection is working fine, Data collection is refreshed every 5 mins.

From the service SAP CPI dev configuration in Integration and Exception Monitoring, I'm not able to change the frequency for the service from 5 mins to 8 hours. The field is fixed at 5 mins and cannot be edited.

The in-app help says this about this parameter:
Defines the frequency for the calculation job. The default is 5 minutes and you cannot change this value. This implies that the calculation for issues detected event is done every 5 minutes. 

Is it really impossible to edit the value in this field?

Thanks

entry.title: Data Access and Export for Concur Expense - Your Digital Tax Audit Assistant
entry.content:
This is a product update that you may not have received because this add-on product for Concur Expense was launched only in Germany in February 2025. However, it also affects all international Concur Expense clients who reimburse expenses in Germany.

Below you'll find high level information that may be relevant for you in the following cases:

  • your finance or payroll department in Germany requests structured and machine-readable data extracts for audit purposes
  • you have already created or you were requested to create "Expense Processor (Audit)" user profiles for audit purposes

This article is also available in our SAP Concur Community (Admin Group Forum) .

Simplify Tax Audits – With Minimal Effort and Maximum Control
You can use Data Access and Export service for Concur Expense to easily face internal and external audits of your Concur expense reports.

Few clicks are enough – and you provide the tax office or your internal audit with the exact data they want to see. No more and no less. This saves you time, reduces compliance risks, and maintains full control over your sensitive data.

The service makes it easy for you to comply with your duty to collaborate in tax audits.

Audit-relevant data at the push of a button
Whether the tax authority wants to access your billing data directly or requires a data export, every audit is tedious for your team – from compiling the relevant evidence to securing sensitive company information. Data Access and Export simplifies this process. Tax auditors and internal auditors get a quick overview of the data on the intuitive Web interface or they use a data extract in the standardized AIS format.

If required, they can navigate to the details. This saves valuable resources on both sides for a smooth and speedy audit.

Why is this relevant for Concur Expense?
Concur Expense is the source of truth for many tax-relevant calculations and payouts. This affects value added tax, income tax, but above all the employees’ wage tax.

For this reason, the tax authorities check this data during their external tax audits. Only with Data Access and Export can you quickly and easily restrict data access to the required scope and export large amounts of data in the shortest possible time.

Controlled Environment

  • Easily manage authorizations for data access
  • Quickly select requested time periods and companies
  • Limited access for tax audits

Efficient and convenient

  • Access via simple, intuitive Web interface
  • Immediate export in the established SAP audit format AIS
  • No manual effort for post-processing of exported data

Seamless integration

  • Can be enabled quickly as an add-on for Concur Expense Professional Edition. It is currently available for clients in Germany. Other countries will follow soon.
  • Deployed and managed by SAP as a web service on SAP Business Technology Platform (no own SAP BTP account required)

Want to learn more?
Your SAP Concur Customer Success Manager is here for you. For more information, visit the following pages (available only in German):

  • SAP Concur Webinar
  • Data Access and Export One Pager

entry.title: How to evaluate an idea of custom AI scenario for your business system like SAP S/4HANA Cloud in AI
entry.content:
SAP Business AI has listed all the  pre-delivered AI Scenarios for our business systems like SAP S/4HANA Cloud. Which means once we finished the initial setup like Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Setup Guide, our end users can use the pre-delivered AI Scenarios.

In some situations, our business systems' users and other associates have some genius ideas to use LLM in the system. Then how to quickly evaluate the idea and the Effect of the idea? Give an example, in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Outbound Delivery documents are create again Sales Orders, then the routes are  determined based on route determination logic. Are there any better options? For example, can we ask LLM to give some suggestions on routes based on more information like destinations' weather forecast, or even based on some freight charge information as grounding? I don't know yet. But I can quickly evaluate my idea With SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad before the developer starts to develop. 

Prerequisites:

  • SAP AI Core has been initially set up in your BTP Sub Account.
  • SAP AI Launchpad has been initially set up in your BTP Sub Account.

Steps:

1.  Prepare the data which can fetched from release API or  CDS View.  I have prepared data as the following:
{
    "DeliveryDocument": "80000000",
    "HeaderGrossWeight": "3.000",
    "HeaderNetWeight": "2.700",
    "HeaderWeightUnit": "KG",
    "HeaderVolume": "0.000",
    "HeaderVolumeUnit": "",
    "ShipFromAddress": { //from shop point address
        "CityName": "Palo Alto",
        "CompanyPostalCode": "",
        "CorrespondenceLanguage": "EN",
        "Country": "US",
        "EmailAddress": "",
        "FaxNumber": "",
        "FaxNumberExtension": "",
        "Floor": "",
        "FormOfAddress": "0003",
        "HomeCityName": "",
        "HouseNumber": "3475",
        "HouseNumberSupplementText": "",
        "MobilePhoneNumber": "",
        "PhoneNumber": "",
        "PostalCode": "94304-1355",
        "PrfrdCommMediumType": "",
        "Region": "CA",
        "RoomNumber": "",
        "StreetName": "Deer Creek",
        "StreetPrefixName": "",
        "StreetSuffixName": "",
        "TaxJurisdiction": "GA00000000"
    },
        "ShipToAddress": {   //from ship to party address
        "DeliveryDocument": "80000000",
        "PartnerFunction": "SP",
        "AddressID": "22900",
        "BusinessPartnerName1": "Domestic US Customer 1",
        "AddressTimeZone": "EST",
        "CityName": "Atlanta",
        "CompanyPostalCode": "",
        "CorrespondenceLanguage": "EN",
        "Country": "US",
        "EmailAddress": "mrinal.kanti.chanda@sap.com",
        "FaxNumber": "",
        "FaxNumberExtension": "",
        "Floor": "",
        "FormOfAddress": "0003",
        "HomeCityName": "",
        "HouseNumber": "200",
        "HouseNumberSupplementText": "",
        "MobilePhoneNumber": "",
        "PhoneNumber": "999 555 6721",
        "PostalCode": "30315-1402",
        "PrfrdCommMediumType": "",
        "Region": "GA",
        "RoomNumber": "",
        "StreetName": "Augusta Ave SE",
        "StreetPrefixName": "",
        "StreetSuffixName": "",
        "TaxJurisdiction": "GA00000000"
    }
}

 

2.  Test in SAP AI Launchpad:

I prepared the follow Sytem prompt:

You are an expert of logistic.You have received a user's outbound delivery information in JSON. The user need you to suggest a best route based outbound delivery JSON information.

 The User Prompt is the JSON file in Step 1 .

Let's test in SAP AI Launchpad with GPT-4.1.

The following is the response from GPT-4.1

Based on your outbound delivery JSON, here’s your **delivery scenario**:

- **Ship From:** 3475 Deer Creek, Palo Alto, CA 94304-1355
- **Ship To:** 200 Augusta Ave SE, Atlanta, GA 30315-1402
- **Weight:** 3.0 kg (Net: 2.7 kg)
- **Country:** US (Domestic shipment)
- **Time Zone Difference:** Palo Alto (Pacific) → Atlanta (Eastern)
- **No special volume requirement or hazardous cargo flagged**

---

## Best Route Suggestion

### 1. **Route Options Overview**

#### **A. Air Freight**
- **Best for:** Speed (overnight or 1-2 day delivery)
- **Cost:** Highest (but the shipment weight is low, so the cost is manageable)
- **Process:**
  - Pickup from Palo Alto
  - Deliver to SFO, OAK, or SJC airport
  - Direct flight to ATL
  - Local delivery in Atlanta

#### **B. Ground Courier (Expedited)**
- **Best for:** Fast and reliable ground service (2-3 days typical with express)
- **Carriers:** FedEx, UPS, USPS Priority Express, DHL
- **Cost:** Lower than air freight, still fast for lightweight parcels

#### **C. Ground Courier (Standard)**
- **Best for:** Cost efficiency, less urgency (4-6 days)
- **Carriers:** FedEx Ground, UPS Ground, USPS Priority

---

### 2. **Recommended (Best) Route for Your Delivery**

Given your shipment details (very light, no hazardous/volume concerns), and typical business shipping needs:

#### **FedEx/UPS/DHL Express Air Service**
1. **Pickup:** Arrange for parcel pickup at 3475 Deer Creek, Palo Alto, CA.
2. **Transport:** 
   - Collected and sent same day to a regional hub (San Francisco/Oakland/San Jose for air departure).
   - Overnight air transport to Atlanta Hartsfield International Airport.
3. **Delivery:** 
   - Early-morning or same-day handoff for final-mile delivery in Atlanta.
   - Will reach consignee at 200 Augusta Ave SE, Atlanta, within 24-36 hours.

**Features:**
- **Tracking & Signature**: Included.
- **Best for:** Business-critical, customer satisfaction.
- **Estimated Delivery Time:** Next business day or 2 business days.
- **Estimated Cost:** Moderate (due to low parcel weight).

---

### 3. **Alternative: Ground Courier Service**

If premium speed is not critical:

- **FedEx Ground, UPS Ground, or USPS Priority Mail**
- Delivery estimate: 4-6 business days
- Pickup same as above, direct line haul across the US
- Cost: Lower

---

## **Suggested Carrier and Service**

- **Carrier:** FedEx, UPS, or DHL Express (all ideal for coast-to-coast shipments)
- **Service:** FedEx Priority Overnight, UPS Next Day Air Saver, or DHL Express Worldwide
- **Booking:** You can book online, arrange for pickup, label your parcel at origin. Given the low weight, most shipping managers select air express for coast-to-coast in the US.

---

### **Route Mapping Summary**

```
1. Palo Alto, CA (your facility)
      ↓
2. SFO/SJC/OAK Airport (CA hub, air transfer)
      ↓
3. ATL Airport (GA hub, air arrival)
      ↓
4. Atlanta last-mile depot
      ↓
5. 200 Augusta Ave SE, Atlanta, GA (customer)
```

---

## **Action Steps**
- Package and label your shipment.
- Get quotes from FedEx, UPS, DHL online or through your logistics provider for **air express service**.
- Book for next day pickup/drop-off.
- Share tracking with your customer.

**Note:** If your delivery is not time-critical or if budget is the priority, use a ground service instead, accepting the longer transit time.

---

**Do you need carrier recommendations, rate estimation, or step-by-step booking guidance?** Let me know how I can specifically assist next!

Of course, you can adjust the prompt or even you grounding some document information in AI Launchpad.

If the result is acceptable, then Architecture can design. Then the developer can start to realize back end with CAP NodeJS, CAP Java, RAP(Cloud ABAP), Python. The listed Languages are supported by the SAP AI SDK.

The end!

Thanks for your time!

Jacky Liu

entry.title: Re: STO stock still in inventory after transfer
entry.content: Since you used the word 'backflush' not sure whether you intentionally used, but for information, backflush is usually triggered during production order confirmation, where components are automatically issued from inventory. In a stock transfer scenario, especially between plants, goods issue must be posted explicitly. Check material document flow for the STO. Check the delivery status and movement types used. Confirm whether the goods issue was posted from the supplying plant. Normally, movement types 303 or 641 would be used which would post the stock-in-transit. So to check which movement types are used, either you can check via MIGO or MB51

entry.title: Analyzing Availability in the Display Product Availability App
entry.content:
In the previous blog that introduced the Display Product Availability, we talked about providing you with the capability to dive deep into how a product’s availability is determined. That plan has been realized, and the Analyze Product Availability feature is here! 

When you view the availability of products in the Display Product Availability app, you can now go to a specific plant and view details, such as the supply and demand elements (referred to as MRP elements) that affect the product’s availability.  

You can also explore further and see how the scope of availability check is configured for the product. The scope of check also tells you the check horizon setting, which helps you understand the calculation of the confirmed quantity of a product.  

Let’s go through the features one by one. 

See MRP elements and other details

To get started with analyzing product availability, in the Display Product Availability app, choose a specific Plant where you want to examine the availability situation. 

For that Plant, you will find details of the availability situation. You can use this information to:  

  • Understand the confirmations of requirements. For example, you can see why you have certain available quantities on a given date, or be aware of a concurrent demand that consumes the stock or receipt quantity. 
  • Analyze the availability situation so that you can reliably respond to customer demands or share internally with other stakeholders.

There are several actions you can carry out: 

  • Drill down on each MRP element to see which document contributes to the availability situation. 
  • Hover over the Available Quantity — You’ll find the total receipts and requirements, and the quantity that is reserved for future requirements. The reserved quantity considers protected quantity reserved for prioritized customers if supply protection is included in the scope of check. For information about supply protection, see Supply Protection (SUP). 
  • Adjust the date range in the Receipts and Requirements table to find out the planned changes in availability. 
  • Examine the scope of check. 

Show scope of check

You can choose „Show Scope of Check“ to see which stocks, receipts, requirements, and other MRP elements are considered for the availability check. For example, if supply protection is included (With Supply Protection for Specific Document Types under Special Scenarios is checked) in the scope of check, then the protected quantity will be included in calculating the product’s availability. 

The scope of check is based on the checking group assigned to the product in the material master, and the checking rule. The checking rule is based on the availability context (sales, or delivery) you selected in combination with the special stock type, if selected. 

You can expand Result After Check Horizon to know the check horizon settings in the material master for this plant. Depending on the settings here, demands and receipts after the check horizon may or may not be considered in the Available-To-Promise check.  

If the Result After Check Horizon is set to Full Confirmation, then the requirements after the check horizon are confirmed fully. Once they move inside the check horizon, the requirements immediately reserve quantity. If the setting is Zero Confirmation, then the requirements after the check horizon are not confirmed; they remain backordered. If Ignore Check Horizon is checked, then requirements are confirmed according to the available stocks and supply elements. These settings explain why the available quantity can be negative, zero, or unlimited, other than positive.  

By offering greater transparency into the factors that impact product availability, you can better track your products’ availability. 

Link to product assistance: Analyzing Product Availability

entry.title: Writing SAP CAP services in Kotlin
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP CAP has become a very popular way to write BTP services & is available in Node.js and Java flavours. I became curious recently if anyone had tried to write a CAP service using Kotlin, a JetBrains developed language which also runs on the JVM. Kotlin supports interoperability with Java, which in theory should mean that we can write our CAP service code in Kotlin, right? 

 

Setting up our test service

Let's start by running the CAP Java Maven archectype provided in the getting started documentation, using the following command. When this command is run, we will be prompted for a 'groupId' and an 'artefactId'. I used 'com.sap.test' and 'ktcap', but feel free to use whatever values you want.

mvn archetype:generate -DarchetypeArtifactId="cds-services-archetype" -DarchetypeGroupId="com.sap.cds" -DarchetypeVersion="RELEASE" -DinteractiveMode=true

Once the process has completed you should see a new CAP Java project contained within a subfolder, but if you open it in an IDE you'll notice that we don't have any code or schema definitions. Luckily the getting started docs also provide us with a CDS Maven plugin to give us a simple bookstore example.

mvn com.sap.cds:cds-maven-plugin:add -Dfeature=TINY_SAMPLE

Now we should have some entities defined in the db/data-model.cds file, as well as a handler Java file at srv/src/java/.../handlers/CatalogServiceHandler.java. Let's try to build & run the code to make sure we have a working service.

mvn spring-boot:run

 Your code should build successfully & once you see the following log, your server is started.

INFO 81621 --- [  restartedMain] o.s.b.w.embedded.tomcat.TomcatWebServer  : Tomcat started on port 8080 (http) with context path '/'

Navigate to http://localhost:8080 in your browser and click on the "Books" OData endpoint. You should see some data, similar to the below screenshot. 

A Quick note for IntelliJ users

You may notice when you try to look at the handler code in IntelliJ that you are seeing a lot of errors, similar to the screenshot below.

When the CAP build happens (which it does as part of our previous maven command) it generates a lot of new java files located in the src/gen folder. Because IntelliJ doesn't know about this, it doesn't understand all of the references in our source code. You can easily resolve this issue by going to the src/gen/java folder in the "Project" panel of IntelliJ, right clicking the folder and selecting "Mark Directory as" > "Generated sources root". 

 

Inspecting the handler code

@Component
@ServiceName(CatalogService_.CDS_NAME)
public class CatalogServiceHandler implements EventHandler {

	@After(event = CqnService.EVENT_READ)
	public void discountBooks(Stream<Books> books) {
		books.filter(b -> b.getTitle() != null && b.getStock() != null)
		.filter(b -> b.getStock() > 200)
		.forEach(b -> b.setTitle(b.getTitle() + " (discounted)"));
	}

}

The sample handler code CAP gave us is pretty straightforward. Basically what we need to know is:

  • The class is annotated as a "Component", which will enable the class to be automatically detected and registered as a spring bean in the Spring Application Context.
  • The class implements an interface EventHandler which enables CAP to distinguish the spring bean as one that may contain event handler methods.
  • It is also annotated with @ServiceName. This tells CAP for which service the handler functions should be registered. In our case we have only defined one service; CatalogService, in the srv folder.
  • Finally we have a function which appends "(discounted)" to any book with more than 200 copies in stock. This function is marked with the @After annotation, which registers the function as a handler to be executed after the On handlers.

Let's try to do something similar in Kotlin.

 

Basic Kotlin Handler

// src/main/java/com/sap/test/ktcap/handlers/TestKotlinHandler.kt

package com.sap.test.ktcap.handlers

import cds.gen.catalogservice.Books
import cds.gen.catalogservice.CatalogService_
import com.sap.cds.services.cds.CqnService
import com.sap.cds.services.handler.EventHandler
import com.sap.cds.services.handler.annotations.After
import com.sap.cds.services.handler.annotations.ServiceName
import org.springframework.stereotype.Component
import java.util.stream.Stream

@Component
@ServiceName(CatalogService_.CDS_NAME)
class TestKotlinHandler: EventHandler {

    @After(event = [CqnService.EVENT_READ])
    fun appendKotlinStr(books: Stream<Books>){
        books.forEach { b -> b.title += " was processed by Kotlin handler" }
    }
}

Here is a basic Kotlin handler implementation that should simply append some text to the title field of all books returned to the client. When you create this Kotlin file, IntelliJ will detect that we do not have Kotlin configured in our project. Click "configure" on the warning to handle this automatically or alternatively you can manually add kotlin as a dependency in the pom.xml. With kotlin configured for our project, we can build & run the CAP service as before and navigate to the Books endpoint.

Looks like our handler ran as expected! Inspecting the logs we can also see that the handler was registered to the Cds Runtime as expected.

INFO 89519 --- [  restartedMain] c.s.c.s.impl.runtime.CdsRuntimeImpl      : Registered handler class com.sap.test.ktcap.handlers.TestKotlinHandler

With this first handler we have proven that our Kotlin class could be registered as a Spring Bean, a handler in the Cds Runtime and that it can exist alongside other Java code in our service. 

 

Replacing the Java Handler with Kotlin

If you look closer at our previous handler, you may notice there is one issue with our implementation; The handler is still accepting Stream<Books> , a Java steam. So although we have implemented our handler in Kotlin, we are not yet using the Kotlin standard library structures to process the data. Let's see if we can achieve the original Java handler functionality by re-writing our Kotlin handler.

As per the CAP documentation, we don't actually need to accept a stream in our function signature - we can accept any Collection or a singular cds type (if we know we are only dealing with one item). So let's try to use a Kotlin List and see if the handler behaves as it did before.

@After(event = [CqnService.EVENT_READ])
fun appendKotlinStr(books: MutableList<Books>)

Recompiling & running the code gives us the same behaviour as before, so we should be able to continue using collections from the Kotlin standard library in our final implementation.

package com.sap.test.ktcap.handlers

import cds.gen.catalogservice.Books
import cds.gen.catalogservice.CatalogService_
import com.sap.cds.services.cds.CqnService
import com.sap.cds.services.handler.EventHandler
import com.sap.cds.services.handler.annotations.After
import com.sap.cds.services.handler.annotations.ServiceName
import org.springframework.stereotype.Component

@Component
@ServiceName(CatalogService_.CDS_NAME)
class TestKotlinHandler: EventHandler {

    @After(event = [CqnService.EVENT_READ])
    fun appendKotlinStr(books: MutableList<Books>){
        books
            .filter { b -> b.title != null && b.stock != null }
            .filter { b -> b.stock > 200 }
            .forEach { b -> b.title += " was processed by Kotlin handler" }
    }
}

  And a final compile & run to check that we get the result we expect..

Nice! Our handler is now affecting only the records with more than 200 copies in stock, just like the original Java handler. The only difference is that we are not using a stream, which we can easily introduce by changing line 17 to books.asSequence() and then chaining our filters as normal, if desired.

 

Conclusion

What we have proven with the above PoC is that Kotlin/Java interoperability works pretty nicely within an SAP CAP application, at least in this basic scenario. We were able to:

  • Implement a working Kotlin handler
  • Register the class as a spring bean within a Spring Java Application
  • Register the handler within the CdsRuntime
  • Process the generated Java "Books" class within a Kotlin data structure

Now we know that we can do it, the question is - should we? Well, Kotlin gives us some pretty nice language features that are not available in Java, for example:

  • Extensions, the ability to extend classes from 3rd party packages without inheriting from them 
  • Compile time nullability checks
  • Coroutines, an asynchronous programming technique similar to Go's goroutines
  • A more concise, intuitive syntax

However, given that we are writing our Kotlin code within two frameworks (CAP & Spring) which were written specifically for Java, there is a risk that differences between how the languages implement null checking, reflection or asynchronocity could result in adverse behaviour at runtime. Even in these cases, it's nice to know that we can fall back to a pure Java class within the same project if needed.

entry.title: Re: Is there a way to extract open accounting periods in...
entry.content:
Hi,

Unfortunately, SAP Public Cloud does not currently provide standard APIs or CDS views specifically designed to retrieve open/unclosed accounting periods in a straightforward manner. However, there are several approaches you can consider to address your billing document cancellation control requirements:

Alternative Solutions

1. BAdI Implementation for Flexible Cancellation Control You can implement the Business Add-In (BAdI) SD_BIL_FLEX_CANCELLATION to create custom logic that controls billing document cancellations [1]. This BAdI allows you to:

  • Evaluate billing document header fields including posting status
  • Determine whether cancellation is allowed based on your business requirements
  • Set different posting dates to ensure cancellation documents are posted to intended periods

2. Posting Date Decoupling The BAdI enables you to decouple the posting date of the cancellation document from the billing date, allowing you to freely determine the target posting period for billing document cancellations [1]. For example, if you need to cancel a customer invoice with a billing date from a closed period, you can retain the original billing date while setting the posting date to fall within the currently open period [1].

[1] Flexible Billing Document Cancellation

Best regards, Dequan Xu

entry.title: Bottle Condition Type for PO - SAP
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

I have a requirement to create a condition type for bottle deposit in the Purchase Order (PO).

I created a condition type ZBEP with the following configuration:

  • Condition Class: A (Discount or Surcharge)

  • Condition Type: C

  • Condition Category: F (Delivery Cost)

  • Item Condition: Checked

  • Deletion Indicator: Checked

  • Amount/Percent: Checked

  • Value: Checked

  • Calculation Type: Checked

  • Accruals: Checked

In the pricing procedure:

  • I added the condition type ZBEP with counter = 0

  • Marked Print = 'X'

  • Assigned both an account key and accrual key

I also maintained the condition record successfully, and the ZBEP condition appears correctly in the PO.

However, during invoice verification (MIRO), the deposit amount is not included in the invoice value.

For example:

  • PO Price = 150

  • Tax = 9

  • Bottle Deposit (ZBEP) = 12
    → Expected Invoice Total = 150 + 9 + 12 = 171
    → Actual Invoice Total = Only 150 + 9 = 159

The deposit amount (12) is missing from the invoice calculation.

Could you please advise what configuration might be missing or incorrect?

Additionally, I would like the deposit amount to be printed on the PO PDF output. Guidance on how to include this in the PO form would also be appreciated.

Thank you in advance for your support

entry.title: Re: Why SAP ISA-M Still Matters – A Strategic Foundation for Modern Integration
entry.content:
Ok, thanks. Meanwhile I have few comments.

1. Implementation and Real-Life Use

  • Can you share real-world examples where ISA-M guided a successful implementation using SAP Integration Suite?

  • How have other companies used ISA-M to prioritize interfaces for modernization, especially under resource constraints?

  • What’s the most efficient way to categorize 100+ existing interfaces using ISA-M's use case classification?

2. Integration Strategy and Governance

  • What governance model do you recommend for a hybrid setup involving CPI, non-SAP APIs, and legacy systems?

  • How can we leverage ISA-M to enforce design standards (e.g., event vs. traditioal methods) across multiple teams and vendors?

  • Do you have templates for an Integration Control Board (ICB) or similar decision-making body based on ISA-M?

3. Tooling and Automation

  • How can tools like LeanIX, Signavio, and SAP Integration Suite be integrated practically under the ISA-M framework?

  • Does SAP provide any accelerators or templates to load existing interface data into LeanIX or Signavio for assessment?

  • Can ISA-M be automated using SAP Cloud ALM to track integration health and roadmap progress?

4. Clean Core and Event-Driven Architecture

  • How can ISA-M guide the transition to SAP Advanced Event Mesh in a Clean Core context?

  • What criteria from ISA-M help decide whether to expose something as an API vs. an event or IDoc?

5. Community Best Practices and Change Management

  • What are some common pitfalls teams face when applying ISA-M in complex organizations with multiple LoBs?

  • Are there any customer success stories or communities where ISA-M knowledge is being actively shared?

entry.title: Re: Error en nota de Criterio al articulo 29 de la Ley de...
entry.content:
Hola a todos,

siguiendo las recomendaciones de Hugo, para que PRDNT no tome valores en retro y muestre el error en la regla X030 y no mover la clase de tratamiento, se puede hacer lo siguiente:

Crear una constante en V_T511K, en mi caso el periodo actual es 27.07.2025, es decir el cambio es válido con un 1 en esa constante.

luego crear una reglita para tomar el valor de la constante, regresando  un False si la fecha es menor o un True si es mayor o igual a la fecha del periodo actual

por ultimo modificar el esquema para que solo el cambio sea válido en True y False tenga el comportamiento anterior

 

Entonces en periodos retro va a tomar la funcionalidad anterior:

y a partir del periodo acutal, tomará lo descrito en la nota

Espero que les sea útil

saludos!

Johnatan
